title: Authors and Citation
text: Benjamin L Hlina. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Hlina, B.L., Birceanu, O., Robinson, C.S., Dhiyebi, H., Wilkie, M.P. 2021. relationship thermal physiology lampricide sensitivity larval sea lamprey (Petromyzon marinus). Journal Great Lakes Research 47: S272-S284. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jglr.2021.10.002
code: @Article{,   title = {The relationship between thermal physiology and lampricide          sensitivity in larval sea lamprey (Petromyzon marinus)},   author = {Benjamin L. Hlina and Oana Birceanu and Christopher S. Robinson and Hadi Dhiyebi and Michael P. Wilkie},   journal = {Journal of Great Lakes Research 47: S272-S284B. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jglr.2021.10.002},   year = {2021}, }

title: Analysis of Ecotoxicology
text: {ecotox} created simple approach using either probit logit analysis calculate lethal concentration (LC) time (LT) appropriate fiducial confidence limits desired selected LC LT ecotoxicology studies (Finney 1971; Wheeler et al. 2006; Robertson et al. 2007). simplicity {ecotox} comes syntax implies within functions similar functions like glm() lm(). addition simplicity syntax, comprehensive tibble produced gives user predicted LC LT value desired level suite parameters fiducial confidence limits, z-value, slope. {ecotox} built published Hlina et al. 2021.

title: Analysis of Ecotoxicology
text: can install CRAN released version {ecotox} CRAN : can install developer version {ecotox} github :

title: Analysis of Ecotoxicology
text: example uses LC_probit function calculate LC50 LC99 probit analysis: See StackExchange post differences using cbind() vs. response / total cbind() function R logistic regression. Example using ratio_test Wheeler et al. 2006 determine differences LC values:
code: ## Calculate LC50 and LC99 head(lamprey_tox)  ## within the dataframe used, control dose, unless produced a value ## during experimentation, are removed from the dataframe, ## as glm cannot handle values of infinite. Other statistical programs ## make note of the control dose but do not include within analysis.   ## calculate LC50 and LC99 for May  m <- LC_probit((response / total) ~ log10(dose),                p = c(50, 99),                weights = total,                data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],                subset = c(month == "May"))  ## view calculated LC50 and LC99 for seasonal toxicity of a pisicide, ## 3-trifluoromethyl-4-nitrophenol (TFM) to lamprey in 2011  m  ## several new features include 1) being able to change the output length  ## 2) you can indicate whether the x variable has been log10 transformed or  ## not if it has the output will take that into consideration  m_2 <- LC_probit((response / total) ~ dose,                  p = c(50, 99),                  weights = total,                  data = lamprey_tox,                  subset = c(month == "May"),                   log_x = FALSE,                   long_output = FALSE)                    ## view calculated LC50 and LC99 for seasonal toxicity of a pisicide, ## 3-trifluoromethyl-4-nitrophenol (TFM) to lamprey in 2011.  m_2 ## Additionally changes have been made to allow for the user  ## to use `cbind()` method when specificying the response variable    m_3 <- LC_probit(cbind(response, survive) ~ log10(dose),                  p = c(50, 99),                  data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],                  subset = c(month == "May"))                     m_3   # notice that m and m_3 produce the same results, however m_3 will produce  # a warning to ensure you have not weighted the model as it is not necessary ## A new function `ratio_test` has been added   # view lamprey_tox data  head(lamprey_tox)  # using glm() to detemine LC values using probit model for May and June  m <- glm((response / total) ~ log10(dose),          data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],          subset = c(month == "May"),          weights = total,          family = binomial(link = "probit"))   j <- glm((response / total) ~ log10(dose),          data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],          subset = c(month == "June"),          weights = total,          family = binomial(link = "probit"))  # now that both May and June models have been made. use ratio_test to # compare LC50 values or whatever LC values of interest.  ratios <- ratio_test(model_1 = m, model_2 = j,                       percentage = 50,                       compare = "May - June")  # view ratio test results  ratios  # you can also use LC_* or LT_* objects to create the models and use ratio test:  m_1 <- LC_probit((response / total) ~ log10(dose), p = c(50, 99),                  weights = total,                  data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],                  subset = c(month == "May"))    j_1 <- LC_probit((response / total) ~ log10(dose), p = c(50, 99),                  weights = total,                  data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],                  subset = c(month == "June"))    ratios_2 <- ratio_test(model_1 = m_1, model_2 = j_1,                         percentage = 50,                        compare = "May - June",                         obj_type = "df")  ratios_2

title: Analysis of Ecotoxicology
text: Finney, D.J., 1971. Probit analysis. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, England. ISBN: 052108041X Wheeler, M.W., Park, R.M., Bailey, .J. 2006. Comparing median lethal concentration values using confidence interval overlap ratio tests. Environ. Toxic. Chem. 25(5), 1441-1444. 10.1897/05-320R.1 Robertson, J.L., Savin, N.E., Russell, R.M. Preisler, H.K., 2007. Bioassays arthropods. CRC press. ISBN: 0849323312 Version 1.4.4 written Benjamin L. Hlina, Carleton University, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada. Written ‘Programming Language R’, R version 4.1.1 (2021-08-10) – “Kick Things”. Source code available {ecotox} contacting Benjamin L. Hlina benjamin.hlina@gmail.com

title: Lethal Concentration Logit — LC_logit
text: Calculates lethal concentration (LC) fiducial confidence limits (CL) using logit analysis according Finney 1971, Wheeler et al. 2006, Robertson et al. 2007.

title: Lethal Concentration Logit — LC_logit
code: LC_logit(formula, data, p = NULL, weights = NULL,          subset = NULL, log_base = NULL,          log_x = TRUE, het_sig = NULL,          conf_level = NULL, conf_type = NULL,          long_output = TRUE)

title: Lethal Concentration Logit — LC_logit
text: formula object class formula one can coerced class): symbolic description model fitted. details model specification given Details. data optional data frame, list environment (object coercible .data.frame data frame) containing variables model. found data, variables taken environment(formula), typically environment LC_logit called. p Lethal Concentration (LC) values given p, example return LC50 value p equals 50. one LC value wanted specify creating vector. LC values can calculated 1e-16 percentage (e.g. LC99.99). However, tibble produced can round nearest whole number. weights vector 'prior weights' used fitting process. needs supplied taking response / total response variable within formula call LC_probit. Otherwise use cbind(response, non-response) method need supply weights. model incorrect. supply weights warning help make sure using one method .See following StackExchange post differences cbind() function R logistic regression. subset allows data subseted desired. Default set NULL. log_base default 10 used  calculate results using anti log10() given x variable log10 transformed. FALSE results back transformed. log_x default TRUE calculate results using antilog determined log_base given x variable log() transformed. FALSE results back transformed. het_sig significance level person's chi square goodness--fit test used decide heterogeneity factor used. NULL set 0.15. conf_level adjust confidence level necessary NULL set 0.95. conf_type default "fl" calculate fudicial confidence limits per Finney 1971. set "dm" delta method used instead. long_output default TRUE return tibble 17 variables. FALSE tibble returned consist p level, n, predicted LC given p level, lower upper confidence limits.

title: Lethal Concentration Logit — LC_logit
text: Returns tibble predicted LC given p level, lower CL (LCL), upper CL (UCL), Pearson's chi square goodness--fit test (pgof), slope, intercept, slope intercept p values standard error, LC variance.

title: Lethal Concentration Logit — LC_logit
text: Finney, D.J., 1971. Probit Analysis, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, England, ISBN: 052108041X Wheeler, M.W., Park, R.M., Bailey, .J., 2006. Comparing median lethal concentration values using confidence interval overlap ratio tests, Environ. Toxic. Chem. 25(5), 1441-1444.10.1897/05-320R.1 Robertson, J.L., Savin, N.E., Russell, R.M. Preisler, H.K., 2007. Bioassays arthropods. CRC press. ISBN: 9780849323317

title: Lethal Concentration Logit — LC_logit
code: head(lamprey_tox) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   nominal_dose tank  month  dose response survive total #>          <dbl> <chr> <chr> <dbl>    <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl> #> 1          0   S     May    0.19        0      20    20 #> 2          0.7 A     May    0.79        0      20    20 #> 3          0.7 L     May    0.8         1      19    20 #> 4          0.7 M     May    0.76        0      20    20 #> 5          1.1 B     May    1.36       13       8    21 #> 6          1.1 K     May    1.22       10       9    19  # within the dataframe used, control dose, unless produced a value # during experimentation, are removed from the dataframe, # as glm cannot handle values of infinite. Other statistical programs # make note of the control dose but do not include within analysis   # calculate LC50 and LC99 for May  m <- LC_logit((response / total) ~ log10(dose), p = c(50, 99),          weights = total,          data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],          subset = c(month == "May"))   # OR  m1 <- LC_logit(cbind(response, survive) ~ log10(dose), p = c(50, 99),                data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],                subset = c(month == "May")) #> Warning: Are you using cbind(response, non-response) method as your y variable, if so do not weight the model. If you are using (response / total) method, model needs the total of test organisms per dose to weight the model properly   # view calculated LC50 and LC99 for seasonal toxicity of a pisicide, # to lamprey in 2011  m #> # A tibble: 2 × 19 #>       p     n  dose   LCL   UCL    se chi_square    df pgof_sig     h slope #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>      <dbl> <int>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1    50    18  1.26  1.19  1.31  1.02       15.2    16    0.509     1  18.3 #> 2    99    18  2.24  2.04  2.59  1.06       15.2    16    0.509     1  18.3 #> # ℹ 8 more variables: slope_se <dbl>, slope_sig <dbl>, intercept <dbl>, #> #   intercept_se <dbl>, intercept_sig <dbl>, z <dbl>, var_m <dbl>, #> #   covariance <dbl>  # they are the same  m1 #> # A tibble: 2 × 19 #>       p     n  dose   LCL   UCL    se chi_square    df pgof_sig     h slope #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>      <dbl> <int>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1    50    18  1.26  1.19  1.31  1.02       15.2    16    0.509     1  18.3 #> 2    99    18  2.24  2.04  2.59  1.06       15.2    16    0.509     1  18.3 #> # ℹ 8 more variables: slope_se <dbl>, slope_sig <dbl>, intercept <dbl>, #> #   intercept_se <dbl>, intercept_sig <dbl>, z <dbl>, var_m <dbl>, #> #   covariance <dbl>  # dose-response curve can be plotted using 'ggplot2' # Uncomment the below lines to run create plots  # library(ggplot2)  # lc_may <- subset(lamprey_tox, month %in% c("May"))  # p1 <- ggplot(data = lc_may[lc_may$nominal_dose != 0, ], #              aes(x = log10(dose), y = (response / total))) + # geom_point() + # geom_smooth(method = "glm", #             method.args = list(family = binomial(link = "logit")), #             aes(weight = total), colour = "#FF0000", se = TRUE)  # p1  # calculate LC50s and LC99s for multiple toxicity tests, June, August, and September  j <- LC_logit((response / total) ~ log10(dose), p = c(50, 99),         weights = total,         data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],         subset = c(month == "June"))  a <- LC_logit((response / total) ~ log10(dose), p = c(50, 99),         weights = total,         data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],         subset = c(month == "August"))  s <- LC_logit((response / total) ~ log10(dose), p = c(50, 99),         weights = total,         data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],         subset = c(month == "September"))  # group results together in a dataframe to plot with 'ggplot2'  results <- rbind(m[, c(1, 3:8, 11)], j[,c(1, 3:8, 11)],                  a[, c(1, 3:8, 11)], s[, c(1, 3:8, 11)]) results$month <- factor(c(rep("May", 2), rep("June", 2),                           rep("August", 2), rep("September", 2)),                         levels = c("May", "June", "August", "September"))   # p2 <- ggplot(data = results, aes(x = month, y = dose, #                              group = factor(p), fill = factor(p))) + #   geom_col(position = position_dodge(width = 0.9), colour = "#000000") + #   geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = LCL, ymax = UCL), #                 size = 0.4, width = 0.06, #                 position = position_dodge(width = 0.9))  # p2

title: Lethal Concentration Probit — LC_probit
text: Calculates lethal concentration (LC) fiducial confidence limits (CL) using probit analysis according Finney 1971, Wheeler et al. 2006, Robertson et al. 2007.

title: Lethal Concentration Probit — LC_probit
code: LC_probit(formula, data, p = NULL, weights = NULL,           subset = NULL, log_base = NULL, log_x = TRUE,           het_sig = NULL, conf_level = NULL, conf_type = NULL,           long_output = TRUE)

title: Lethal Concentration Probit — LC_probit
text: formula object class formula one can coerced class): symbolic description model fitted. details model specification given Details. data optional data frame, list environment (object coercible .data.frame data frame) containing variables model. found data, variables taken environment(formula), typically environment LC_probit called. p Lethal Concentration (LC) values given p, example return LC50 value p equals 50. one LC value wanted specify creating vector. LC values can calculated 1e-16 percentage (e.g. LC99.99). However, tibble produced can round nearest whole number. weights vector 'prior weights' used fitting process. needs supplied taking response / total response variable within formula call LC_probit. Otherwise use cbind(response, non-response) method need supply weights. model incorrect. supply weights warning help make sure using one method . See following StackExchanges post differences cbind() function R logistic regression input format binomial glm. subset allows data subseted desired. Default set NULL. log_base default 10 used  calculate results using anti log10() given x variable log10 transformed. FALSE results back transformed. log_x default TRUE calculate results using antilog determined log_base given x variable log() transformed. FALSE results back transformed. het_sig significance level person's chi square goodness--fit test (pgof) used decide heterogeneity factor used. NULL set 0.15. conf_level adjust confidence level necessary NULL set 0.95. conf_type default "fl" calculate fudicial confidence limits per Finney 1971. set "dm" delta method used instead. long_output default TRUE return tibble 17 variables. FALSE tibble returned consist p level, n, predicted LC given p level, lower upper confidence limits.

title: Lethal Concentration Probit — LC_probit
text: Returns tibble predicted LC given p level, lower CL (LCL), upper CL (UCL), Pearson's chi square goodness--fit test (pgof), slope, intercept, slope intercept p values standard error, LC variance.

title: Lethal Concentration Probit — LC_probit
text: Finney, D.J., 1971. Probit Analysis, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, England, ISBN: 052108041X Wheeler, M.W., Park, R.M., Bailey, .J., 2006. Comparing median lethal concentration values using confidence interval overlap ratio tests, Environ. Toxic. Chem. 25(5), 1441-1444.10.1897/05-320R.1 Robertson, J.L., Savin, N.E., Russell, R.M. Preisler, H.K., 2007. Bioassays arthropods. CRC press. ISBN: 9780849323317

title: Lethal Concentration Probit — LC_probit
code: head(lamprey_tox) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   nominal_dose tank  month  dose response survive total #>          <dbl> <chr> <chr> <dbl>    <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl> #> 1          0   S     May    0.19        0      20    20 #> 2          0.7 A     May    0.79        0      20    20 #> 3          0.7 L     May    0.8         1      19    20 #> 4          0.7 M     May    0.76        0      20    20 #> 5          1.1 B     May    1.36       13       8    21 #> 6          1.1 K     May    1.22       10       9    19  # within the dataframe used, control dose, unless produced a value # during experimentation, are removed from the dataframe, # as glm cannot handle values of infinite. Other statistical programs # make note of the control dose but do not include within analysis  # calculate LC50 and LC99  m <- LC_probit((response / total) ~ log10(dose), p = c(50, 99),                weights = total,                data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],                subset = c(month == "May")) # OR  m1 <- LC_probit(cbind(response, survive) ~ log10(dose), p = c(50, 99),                data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],                subset = c(month == "May")) #> Warning: Are you using cbind(response, non-response) method as your y variable, if so do not weight the model. If you are using (response / total) method, model needs the total of test organisms per dose to weight the model properly  # view calculated LC50 and LC99 for seasonal toxicity of a pisicide, # to lamprey in 2011  m #> # A tibble: 2 × 19 #>       p     n  dose   LCL   UCL    se chi_square    df pgof_sig     h slope #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>      <dbl> <int>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1    50    18  1.25  1.18  1.31  1.02       14.1    16    0.590     1  10.3 #> 2    99    18  2.11  1.95  2.35  1.05       14.1    16    0.590     1  10.3 #> # ℹ 8 more variables: slope_se <dbl>, slope_sig <dbl>, intercept <dbl>, #> #   intercept_se <dbl>, intercept_sig <dbl>, z <dbl>, var_m <dbl>, #> #   covariance <dbl>  # these are the same  m1 #> # A tibble: 2 × 19 #>       p     n  dose   LCL   UCL    se chi_square    df pgof_sig     h slope #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>      <dbl> <int>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1    50    18  1.25  1.18  1.31  1.02       14.1    16    0.590     1  10.3 #> 2    99    18  2.11  1.95  2.35  1.05       14.1    16    0.590     1  10.3 #> # ℹ 8 more variables: slope_se <dbl>, slope_sig <dbl>, intercept <dbl>, #> #   intercept_se <dbl>, intercept_sig <dbl>, z <dbl>, var_m <dbl>, #> #   covariance <dbl>  # dose-response curve can be plotted using 'ggplot2'  # library(ggplot2)  # lc_may <- subset(lamprey_tox, month %in% c("May"))  # p1 <- ggplot(data = lc_may[lc_may$nominal_dose != 0, ], #              aes(x = log10(dose), y = (response / total))) + #   geom_point() + #   geom_smooth(method = "glm", #               method.args = list(family = binomial(link = "probit")), #               aes(weight = total), colour = "#FF0000", se = TRUE)  # p1  # calculate LC50s and LC99s for multiple toxicity tests, June, August, and September  j <- LC_probit((response / total) ~ log10(dose), p = c(50, 99),         weights = total,         data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],         subset = c(month == "June"))  a <- LC_probit((response / total) ~ log10(dose), p = c(50, 99),         weights = total,         data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],         subset = c(month == "August"))  s <- LC_probit((response / total) ~ log10(dose), p = c(50, 99),         weights = total,         data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],         subset = c(month == "September"))  # group results together in a dataframe to plot with 'ggplot2'  results <- rbind(m[, c(1, 3:8, 11)], j[,c(1, 3:8, 11)],                  a[, c(1, 3:8, 11)], s[, c(1, 3:8, 11)]) results$month <- factor(c(rep("May", 2), rep("June", 2),                           rep("August", 2), rep("September", 2)),                         levels = c("May", "June", "August", "September"))  # p2 <- ggplot(data = results, aes(x = month, y = dose, #                              group = factor(p), fill = factor(p))) + #   geom_col(position = position_dodge(width = 0.9), colour = "#000000") + #   geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = LCL, ymax = UCL), #                 size = 0.4, width = 0.06, #                 position = position_dodge(width = 0.9))  # p2

title: Lethal Time Logit — LT_logit
text: Calculates lethal time (LT) fiducial confidence limits (CL) using logit analysis according Finney 1971, Wheeler et al. 2006, Robertson et al. 2007.

title: Lethal Time Logit — LT_logit
code: LT_logit(formula, data, p = NULL, weights = NULL,           subset = NULL, log_base = NULL, log_x = TRUE, het_sig = NULL,           conf_level = NULL, long_output = TRUE)

title: Lethal Time Logit — LT_logit
text: formula object class formula one can coerced class: symbolic description model fitted. data optional data frame, list environment (object coercible .data.frame data frame) containing variables model. found data, variables taken environment(formula), typically environment LT_logit called. p Lethal time (LT) values given p, example return LT50 value p equals 50. one LT value wanted specify creating vector. LT values can calculated 1e-16 percentage (e.g. LT99.99).However, tibble produced can round nearest whole number. weights vector 'prior weights' used fitting process. needs supplied taking response / total response variable within formula call LC_probit. Otherwise use cbind(response, non-response) method need supply weights. model incorrect. supply weights warning help make sure using one method . See following StackExchange post differences cbind() function R logistic regression. subset allows data subseted desired. Default set NULL. log_base default 10 used  calculate results using anti log10() given x variable log10 transformed. FALSE results back transformed. log_x default TRUE calculate results using antilog determined log_base given x variable log() transformed. FALSE results back transformed. het_sig significance level person's chi square goodness--fit test used decide heterogeneity factor used. NULL set 0.15. conf_level Adjust confidence level necessary NULL set 0.95. long_output default TRUE return tibble 17 variables. FALSE tibble returned consist p level, n, predicted LC given p level, lower upper confidence limits.

title: Lethal Time Logit — LT_logit
code: head(lamprey_time) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   nominal.dose  dose month  hour response survive total #>          <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <int>    <int>   <int> <int> #> 1          1.1  1.25 May       1        0      58    58 #> 2          1.1  1.25 May       2        0      58    58 #> 3          1.1  1.25 May       3        0      58    58 #> 4          1.1  1.25 May       4        1      57    58 #> 5          1.1  1.25 May       5        5      53    58 #> 6          1.1  1.25 May       6       14      44    58  results <- LT_logit((response / total) ~ log10(hour), p = c(50, 99), weights = total, data = lamprey_time, subset = c(month == "May"))  # view calculated LT50 and LT99 for seasonal # toxicity of a piscicide, 3-trifluoromethyl-4-nitrophenol, to lamprey in 2011  results #> # A tibble: 2 × 17 #>       p     n  time   LCL   UCL chi_square    df pgof_sig     h slope slope_se #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>      <dbl> <int>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1    50    11  9.97  8.85  11.9       16.6     9   0.0551  1.85  6.77    0.734 #> 2    99    11 47.6  30.0  118.        16.6     9   0.0551  1.85  6.77    0.734 #> # ℹ 6 more variables: slope_sig <dbl>, intercept <dbl>, intercept_se <dbl>, #> #   intercept_sig <dbl>, z <dbl>, var_m <dbl>  # dose-response curve can be plotted using 'ggplot2'

text: Returns tibble predicted LT given p level, lower CL (LCL), upper CL (UCL), LCL, Pearson's chi square goodness--fit test (pgof), slope, intercept, slope intercept p values standard error, LT variance.

title: Lethal Time Probit — LT_probit
text: Finney, D.J., 1971. Probit Analysis, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, England, ISBN: 052108041X Wheeler, M.W., Park, R.M., Bailey, .J., 2006. Comparing median lethal concentration values using confidence interval overlap ratio tests, Environ. Toxic. Chem. 25(5), 1441-1444.10.1897/05-320R.1 Robertson, J.L., Savin, N.E., Russell, R.M. Preisler, H.K., 2007. Bioassays arthropods. CRC press. ISBN: 9780849323317

title: Lethal Time Probit — LT_probit
code: head(lamprey_time) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   nominal.dose  dose month  hour response survive total #>          <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <int>    <int>   <int> <int> #> 1          1.1  1.25 May       1        0      58    58 #> 2          1.1  1.25 May       2        0      58    58 #> 3          1.1  1.25 May       3        0      58    58 #> 4          1.1  1.25 May       4        1      57    58 #> 5          1.1  1.25 May       5        5      53    58 #> 6          1.1  1.25 May       6       14      44    58  results <- LT_probit((response / total) ~ log10(hour), p = c(50, 99), weights = total, data = lamprey_time, subset = c(month == "May"))  # view calculated LT50 and LT99 for seasonal # toxicity of a piscicide, 3-trifluoromethyl-4-nitrophenol, to lamprey in 2011  results #> # A tibble: 2 × 19 #>       p     n  time   LCL   UCL    se chi_square    df pgof_sig     h slope #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>      <dbl> <int>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1    50    11  9.99  8.93  11.7  1.05       13.5     9    0.141  1.50  4.00 #> 2    99    11 38.1  26.3   73.7  1.19       13.5     9    0.141  1.50  4.00 #> # ℹ 8 more variables: slope_se <dbl>, slope_sig <dbl>, intercept <dbl>, #> #   intercept_se <dbl>, intercept_sig <dbl>, z <dbl>, var_m <dbl>, #> #   covariance <dbl>  # dose-response curve can be plotted using 'ggplot2'

title: Ratio test — ratio_test
text: Calculates ratio test compare two LC LT values two separate probit logit models. function based ratio test developed Wheeler et al. 2006. 10.1897/05-320R.1 suggested replacement common method comparing confidence intervals determine differences.

title: Ratio test — ratio_test
code: ratio_test(model_1, model_2, percentage = NULL,            type = NULL, compare = NULL, log_base = NULL, log_x = TRUE,            obj_type = NULL, conf_type = NULL)

title: Ratio test — ratio_test
text: model_1 first model used ratio test. object either probit logit model created using glm() function. See example. model_2 second model used ratio test. object either probit logit model created using glm() function. See example. percentage either single value vector given LC LT percentage desired compare. Percentage value used argument p LC_ LT_ functions. example, 50 return compare LC50 values two models. one LC value desired specify creating vector. LC values can calculated 1e-16 percentage (e.g. LC99.99). However, tibble produced can round nearest whole number. type Link type needs specified either "probit" default return used calculations probit model desired LCs LTs. specified "logit" ratio_test return calculate using logit model desired LCs LTs. compare Supply character string used output letting user know models LCs LTs compared. Default output "Model 1 - Model 2". See example. log_base default 10 used  calculate results using anti log10() given x variable log10 transformed. FALSE results back transformed. log_x default TRUE calculate results using antilog determined log_base given x variable log() transformed. FALSE results back transformed. obj_type default  "list" requires model_1 model_2 arguments model objects, form list, glm() functions. Alternatively "df" can used require model_1 model_2 arguments data.frame objects created running either LC_ LT_ functions. conf_type default "fl" "df" supplied correct covariance values h 1 fudicial confidence limits use heterogeneity factor, h, correct variances chi-square p value less 0.15. conf_type can also "dm", delta method, use heterogeneity correction factor therefore covariance uncorrected. argument needed using dataframe objects LC_ LT_ functions used delta method analysis.

title: Ratio test — ratio_test
text: tibble percentage LC LT value desired percentage argument, dose_1 dose_2 displayed calculated backtransformed untransformed doses desired LC LT values. Standard Error (se), Z test statistic (test_stat) p_value determined using Z test statistic determined using formulas Wheeler et al. 2006. .

title: Ratio test — ratio_test
text: Wheeler, M.W., Park, R.M., Bailey, .J., 2006. Comparing median lethal concentration values using confidence interval overlap ratio tests, Environ. Toxic. Chem. 25(5), 1441-1444.10.1897/05-320R.1

title: Ratio test — ratio_test
code: # view lamprey_tox data  head(lamprey_tox) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   nominal_dose tank  month  dose response survive total #>          <dbl> <chr> <chr> <dbl>    <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl> #> 1          0   S     May    0.19        0      20    20 #> 2          0.7 A     May    0.79        0      20    20 #> 3          0.7 L     May    0.8         1      19    20 #> 4          0.7 M     May    0.76        0      20    20 #> 5          1.1 B     May    1.36       13       8    21 #> 6          1.1 K     May    1.22       10       9    19  # using glm() to detemine LC values using probit model for May and June  m <- glm((response / total) ~ log10(dose),          data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],          subset = c(month == "May"),          weights = total,          family = binomial(link = "probit"))   j <- glm((response / total) ~ log10(dose),          data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ],          subset = c(month == "June"),          weights = total,          family = binomial(link = "probit"))  # now that both May and June models have been made. use ratio_test to # compare LC50 values or whatever LC values of interest.  ratios <- ratio_test(model_1 = m, model_2 = j, percentage = 50, compare = "May - June")  # view ratio test results  ratios #> # A tibble: 1 × 7 #>   compare    percentage dose_1 dose_2    se test_stat p_value #>   <chr>           <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1 May - June         50   1.25   2.66 0.110      2.98 0.00292  # you can also use LC_probit to create the models and use ratio test  m_1 <- LC_probit((response / total) ~ log10(dose), p = c(50, 99), weights = total, data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ], subset = c(month == "May"))    j_1 <- LC_probit((response / total) ~ log10(dose), p = c(50, 99), weights = total, data = lamprey_tox[lamprey_tox$nominal_dose != 0, ], subset = c(month == "June"))    ratios_2 <- ratio_test(model_1 = m_1, model_2 = j_1, percentage = 50, compare = "May - June", obj_type = "df")  ratios_2 #> # A tibble: 1 × 7 #>   compare    percentage dose_1 dose_2    se test_stat p_value #>   <chr>           <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1 May - June         50   1.25   2.66 0.110      2.98 0.00292

title: ecotox v1.4.4

title: ecotox v1.4.4
text: LC_ LT_ functions now determine standard error similar predict() works well covariance model used ratio_test() ratio_test() discovered inaccurately calculating test statistic p value log_x = FALSE. corrected determining t taking log doses citation package updated paper package writing now published v1.4.4 pushed CRAN within days

title: ecotox v1.4.4
text: LC_ LT_ functions now warnings messages supplying variable weights argument. due needing supply taking response / total response variable within formula call LC_probit. Otherwise use cbind(response, non-response) method need supply weights. model incorrect. don’t supply weights warning help make sure using one method . stackExchange question explains differences using cbind() vs. respone / total method. cbind() function R logistic regression

title: ecotox v1.4.4
text: Test coverage now 100% functions including ratio_test() LC_ LT_ functions now warnings supplying value p LC_ LT_ functions now error messages supplying variable weights argument. ecotox longer relys ggplot2 ggplot2 dependency examples LC_ LT_ functions use ggplot2 plot results. Instead examples now commented. run part example just uncomment lines. done ggplot2 need dependency ecotox. tibble stats now dependency stats truely necessary dependency ecotox. tibble used instead R’s default dataframe tibbles useful necssary anlysis.

title: ecotox v1.4.4
text: type now null default "probit" can "logit" specified compare argument added. adds compare column output letting user know models compared. Current default stats "Model 1 - Model 2". However, can specificy vector characters like compare = c("May - June")

title: ecotox v1.4.4
text: New function, ratio_test. function allows user caculate differences two seperate LC LT values using ratio test derived Wheeler et al. 2006. use function, user needs create two glm() objects either probit logit link. Model objects can passed ratio_test() along percent argument argument p argument LC_ LT_ functions. type argument also needed specify link function used glm(). can either "probit" "logit". functions now output tibble instead dataframe New argument log_base LC, LT, ratio_test functions. allows user specifcy base used log transfoming dose/x variable. functions now allow LC LT value calculated 1.0e-16 percent however four decmial places typically appropriate (e.g. LC75.5). Tibble output usually round p value nearest whole number insepect p column export excel using openxlsx package ’ll see p output value supplied function call.

title: ecotox v1.4.4
text: functions now long_output argument allows user decide whether short long output displayed. Default TRUE display long output 19 variables. FALSE used 7 variables displayed.

title: ecotox v1.4.4
text: functions now log_x argument allows user specify x variable log10 transformed . Default TRUE output back transformed results. FALSE results back transformed. LT_logit producing error variance co-variance matrix created analysis required heterogenitity correction factor. fixed variance co-variance matrix produced whether hetrogenity correction factor needed. Tests updated comprehensive ‘ecotox’

title: ecotox v1.4.4
text: functions now subset argument Data argument can now just dataframe interest need use brackets subset Weights longer optional argument can specified just object name. need add name dataframe, bracket subset [] $ select object used weights. LC_probit LC_logit LT_probit LT_logit might depreciated lc_probit lc_logit lt_probit lt_logit simpler function calls users consistent naming conventions. Thoughts??

text: ecotox now operation 3 months. ’ve made recent improvements, e.g. subset feature, still working spearman_karber function hope implement within next month . three functions want implement: Ratio comparison test comparing LCs LTs following Wheeler et al. 2006 parallelism test following Robertson et al. 2007 equality test following Robertson et al. 2007. features functions people want see? people think current functions currently development?
